items.title: What you need to know about new CSS in 2022
items.content:
Frontend Focus

üá∫üá¶ #‚Äã542 ‚Äî May 18, 2022 | Read on the web

The State of CSS in 2022 ‚Äî An introduction and overview of the CSS features and browser changes on slate for the rest of the year. There‚Äôs a lot to look through here, including :has(), Viewport unit variants, subgrid, color-mix(), and much more. It‚Äôs a solid high level look at what you need to know about writing CSS in 2022 and beyond, with examples/resources to boot. There‚Äôs also an accompanying video version¬†here.

Adam Argyle

Web Applications 101 ‚Äî A single article that touches on almost everything involved in building a modern Web site from the simplest of HTML pages through to server-side rendering (SSR) and static-site generation (SSG). Not a tutorial but gives you the broader, architectural¬†picture.

Robin Wieruch

How to Create Dynamic Forms Using FormArray in Angular ‚Äî Have you ever booked movie tickets online? If yes, then you have used a dynamic form. In this article, you‚Äôll learn to create a dynamic form in Angular and also hear a high-level explanation of other useful classes of Angular reactive¬†forms.

Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

New WebKit Features in Safari 15.5 ‚Äî Safari 15.5 is here, with support for the inert attribute, the worker-src Content Security Policy directive, APIs for implementing new viewport units in WKWebView, and many¬†fixes.

Jen Simmons (WebKit)

‚ö°Ô∏è Quick bits:

  • Privacy is an essential part of the web. Now, the W3C TAG Privacy Principles Task Force has released a first public working draft of the Privacy Principles.

  • The Chrome team have decided to postpone the restriction on SharedArrayBuffer on desktop to Chrome 106 ‚Äî it's to secure more time to introduce ways to relax the requirement to enable cross-origin isolation.

  • CSS Day is back in person next month. There's still a few tickets left if you fancy a trip to Amsterdam.

  • Dev browser Polypane just hit version nine, adding a screenshot editor, structured data support and new debug tools.

  • For the first time in a very long time, WordPress' market share is shrinking.

  • So, what happens to a TLD when a country stops existing?

  • This site highlights examples of low-carbon web design and development You can submit a site for inclusion too if you'd like.

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

:where() :is() :has()? New CSS Selectors That Make Your Life Easier ‚Äî An approachable look at these three new CSS selectors, how to use them, and the current levels of browser support for¬†each.

Kilian Valkhof (Polypane)

Rethinking Server-Timing as a Critical Monitoring Tool ‚Äî Server-Timing is uniquely powerful as the only HTTP response header that supports setting free-form values for a specific resource and making them accessible via a browser API separate from the Request/Response references¬†themselves.

Sean Roberts

Level-Up Your Cypress Testing Knowledge for Free ‚Äî Learn from top industry experts with over 25 lessons on how to get started with¬†Cypress.

Cypress.io sponsor

Syntax Highlighting (and More) with Prism on a Static Site ‚Äî This post will show you how to implement syntax highlighting on a Next.js blog with the popular Prism.js¬†library.

Adam Rackis

Theoretical Foundations for Server-Side Rendering and Static-Rendering ‚Äî A research paper and proposal regarding rendering. It ultimately concludes that the distinction between pre-rendering (static) and SSR is somewhat blurry and proposes an API implementation wherein the framework chooses whether to serve up an existing pre-render or a server-rendered page without the developer needing to specify in¬†advance.

Eric Burel

How Modern Frameworks Perform on the New 'Interaction to Next Paint' (INP)¬†Metric
Leena Sohoni, Addy Osmani, Keen Yee Liau

Quick Tip: You Might Not Need calc()
Michelle Barker

Jobs

Product Designer at Fleet (100% Remote) ‚Äî We're building a better way to manage employee laptops and servers. We're looking for someone with design and frontend experience to join the team and help iterate our web and desktop¬†apps.
Fleet

AI & Software Engineers ‚Äî Sticker Mule is the Internet's most "kick ass" brand. Our software team operates from 17 countries, and we're always looking for more exceptional¬†engineers.
Sticker mule

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired ‚Äî Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free for¬†job-seekers.
Hired

üîß Code, Tools & Resources

Reagraph: WebGL Graph Visualizations for React ‚Äî A high-performance network graph visualization library that uses WebGL under the hood for both 2D and 3D rendering options. Here‚Äôs a basic sandbox example you can play¬†with.

REAVIZ

Tweetic: Convert Tweets to Static HTML ‚Äî Useful to preserve the look of a tweet longterm or possibly in HTML email. Also gives you the option to use plain CSS or Tailwind for the¬†styling.

Zernonia

DFlex: A Drag-and-Drop Library for All JS Frameworks ‚Äî This is a vanilla JavaScript solution with a focus on good performance and easy implementation. Try some demos here.

DFlex

Find & Fix Your Accessibility Bugs. Free axe DevTools Chrome¬†Extension

Deque sponsor

Parvus: Accessible Lightbox with No Dependencies ‚Äî I love how it says not to use overlays on Web pages but if you have to, use this! There‚Äôs a CodePen¬†example.

Benjamin de Oostfrees

Shrink.media: An Online Tool to Reduce the Size of Images ‚Äî There are certainly lots of similar tools, but this one has a nice UI where you can visually compare the images and use sliders to reduce the quality and physical¬†size.

Shrink.media

Horizon UI: A Beautiful Open Source Admin Template for Chakra UI and React ‚Äî Includes 70+ dark/light components covering a whole slew of UI possibilities. View a live preview¬†here.

Horizon UI

items.title: How to build a useful Web Component
items.content:
Frontend Focus

üá∫üá¶ #‚Äã541 ‚Äî May 11, 2022 | Read on the web

How To Build a Modal Dialog as a Web Component ‚Äî ‚ÄúWrite once and run everywhere, so to speak, or at least that was my lofty aspiration. Good news. It is indeed possible to build a modal with rich interaction that only requires authoring HTML to¬†use.‚Äù

Nathan Smith

Porting Zelda Classic to the Web ‚Äî A fascinating write up of an amazing piece of work.. and there‚Äôs not a single line of JavaScript. It‚Äôs pretty amazing what the browser, WebAssembly, and compiler toolchains can do now and this shows it all off pretty well. If you prefer playing to reading, though, the end result is¬†here.

Connor Clark

Figma for Developers ‚Äî Join Steve Kinney to learn how to confidently use Figma for creating user interface prototypes. You‚Äôll also learn how to create reusable styles, typography, and components to create prototypes to show colleagues or customers before you build an entire¬†application.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Babylon.js 5.0: A Powerful 3D Web Rendering Engine ‚Äî Babylon is a powerful framework you can use as the basis for games, visualizations, and other 3D and AR experiences running both natively and on the Web. As usual, they have a release video showing it off too or hit the playground to get playing with a basic example in¬†seconds.

Babylon.js Project

Building a Musical Instrument with the Web Audio API ‚Äî One of our favorite writers in the frontend space is back with an easy to follow walkthrough of how she built Keyboard Accordion, a Web based diatonic accordion (which I struggle to play in any coherent fashion at all but it sounds¬†great).

Tania Rascia

‚ö°Ô∏è Quick bits:

  • @wayback_exe is a fantastic Twitter account I've been enjoying lately. It posts screenshots of (mostly) ancient Web pages each day.

  • 100 Days to Offload is a group project around publishing 100 posts on your blog within the next year ‚Äì something we wholeheartedly support. Let's bring blogging back!

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

'Please, Stop Disabling Zoom' ‚Äî OK, sometimes there might be a good reason, but 9 times out of 10, you‚Äôre probably going to be causing someone some accessibility problems on mobile, so don‚Äôt just do it without¬†consideration.

Manuel Matuzoviƒá

On Ordering CSS Declarations Alphabetically ‚Äî Jim is sold on the idea of ordering CSS declarations alphabetically, not because it‚Äôs more organized but because it actually forces you to take more¬†care.

Jim Nielsen

Free Chat/Messaging UI Kits for Your Website or App ‚Äî Unlock enterprise-grade features, functions, and UI components completely free for your startup or side project with the Maker Account from¬†Stream.

Stream sponsor

'It‚Äôs Time We Fix The Unethical Design of Cookie Consent Windows' ‚Äî It‚Äôs often just easier to click ‚ÄòAccept‚Äô rather than think about the ramifications of your choices when it comes to cookie consent windows, but could we make things better? The key, says this author, is to make the absolute minimum necessary the default¬†option.

Nicat Manafov

Designing a Better Language Selector ‚Äî Language selectors are common on sites with worldwide audiences but there are so many different approaches. Vitaly looks at a lot of options here and narrows in on what‚Äôs really essential to get¬†right.

Vitaly Friedman

A Dive into Text Wrapping and Word Breaking on the Web ‚Äî A look at ways to control how text wraps (or doesn‚Äôt wrap) on a¬†page.

Will Boyd

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Discussing Front-End Testing with Lucas Da Costa ‚Äî The author of Testing JavaScript Applications (published by Manning) talks about the role of testing in front-end projects and what tools are at your disposal. (38¬†minutes.)

20minJS podcast

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Serverless for Frontend Engineers with Swizec Teller ‚Äî Swizec does courses in using React alongside serverless technologies and speaks with Jeremy and Rebecca here about approaching serverless as a frontend engineer, JavaScript, and troublesome¬†tutorials.

Serverless Chats Podcast podcast

How To Build an Absurdly Backwards Compatible Website
Zachary Flower

On the Capitalization of Vendor-Prefixed CSS Property Names in JavaScript
Alan Hogan

The Joys and Sorrows of Maintaining a Personal Website
The Cheapskate's Guide

Jobs

Senior Vue.js Developer (Remote-Friendly) ‚Äî Software Development Agency in Wroc≈Çaw, Poland working with experts from around the globe to create meaningful¬†software.
Monterail

Frontend Developer at X-Team (Remote) ‚Äî Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, and¬†more.
X-Team

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired ‚Äî Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free for¬†job-seekers.
Hired

üîß Code, Tools & Resources

A Drop-in Minimal CSS Framework Previewer ‚Äî There are a lot of ‚Äòminimal‚Äô CSS frameworks, such as new.css and Primer CSS but it can be hard to trawl through them for something you‚Äôd like. Enter this ‚Äòminimal CSS framework switcher‚Äô where you get to preview lots of minimal CSS frameworks on a single¬†page.

Liam Doherty

Useful Tools for Creating AVIF Images ‚Äî AVIF (AV1 Image File Format) is a modern image file format which offer space and efficiency benefits over legacy alternatives. Its support is good in Firefox and Chrome but Safari has yet to get on¬†board.

Sunkanmi Fafowora

Project Management for Today's (and Tomorrow's) Software¬†Teams

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

CSS Gradient Generator ‚Äî A great web tool for creating ‚Äúbeautiful, lush gradients‚Äù. Nice options to play around with here, and the CSS output can be copied in one¬†click.

Josh W. Comeau

CSS Accordion Slider Generator ‚Äî An online tool for creating basic collapsing content areas (a.k.a. ‚Äòaccordions‚Äô) with CSS and HTML you can copy and paste into your¬†project.

Onur Adsay

Scrollex: A Library to Build Beautiful Scroll Experiences with Minimal Code ‚Äî Definitely not for every project but you can check out some really cool examples of what‚Äôs possible on the demo¬†page.

Austin Malerba

MockRTC: A Powerful WebRTC Mock Peer and Proxy ‚Äî A tool for building automated tests for WebRTC traffic or otherwise debugging WebRTC related work you‚Äôre¬†doing.

HTTP Toolkit

üï∞ ICYMI (Some older stuff that's still worth checking out)

  • Got a new Mac? Robin Wieruch runs through how to set up an M1 machine for web development.
  • This video from Maarten Van Hoof is a good look at how container queries will help us create robust, resuable components with CSS.
  • Why is CSS the way it is? Well, here Jim Nielsen takes a look back to appreciate the things the original authors of CSS got right.
  • Use Netlify's CLI? Here's a quick rundown of things you may not know you can do with it.
  • Plain Text Sports is a simple site that does away with the typical 'cruft and complications' of the modern. So, are we about to see more of this rebeling "against the general overwhelm of the internet"?

items.title: Eric Meyer shows off max-inline-size
items.content:
Frontend Focus

üá∫üá¶ #‚Äã540 ‚Äî May 4, 2022 | Read on the web

You Don‚Äôt Need a UI Framework ‚Äî You‚Äôve got an app or a site to build so you reach for Bootstrap or Material UI and.. well, maybe you shouldn‚Äôt, says Josh, who argues they‚Äôre not needed for most projects and makes his case¬†here.

Josh Comeau

üéÇ ¬†Celebrating Firefox 100: How Mozilla Got There ‚Äî Just a month behind Chrome 100 comes Firefox 100, and how far Firefox has come since its birth as Phoenix, a lightweight rethinking of the former Netscape browser suite. Firefox 100 is broadly not a developer oriented release but there are release notes nonetheless.

Mozilla

Build a More Accessible Web App with axe DevTools ‚Äî Start accessibility testing in your browser in just minutes. Avoid wasted time with inaccurate results. Easily fix issues with in-product guidance. Install the free axe DevTools Chrome extension and start building a more accessible app¬†today.

Deque sponsor

Flexibly Centering an Element with Side-Aligned Content ‚Äî I'm old enough to remember when folks like Eric had to come up with complicated solutions for Web layout issues, so it‚Äôs fantastic things have progressed that such solutions are now simple, yet still clever enough to involve CSS properties I've not used before such as max-inline-size here.

Eric Meyer

Microsoft Edge Overtakes Safari as 2nd Most Popular Desktop Browser ‚Äî So now the #1 and #2 browser are, essentially, both Chromium under the hood for a total of 76.7% share between them. Safari is still huge in the mobile space, however, due to Apple‚Äôs rules around browser engines (or lack thereof) on iOS¬†devices.

MacRumors

‚ö°Ô∏è Quick bits:

  • The CSS Zen Garden project has turned 19 years old.

  • Rachel Andrew reflects on what's was new to the web platform in April 2022.

  • Dave Rupert considers the complexity of server-side versus client-side analytics and concludes "If your goal is not to grow your site‚Ä¶ maybe ignorance is bliss."

  • A neat list of cool things people do with their blogs. Seeing a lot more stuff on Twitter about blogging 'coming back' lately..

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Creating Realistic Reflections with CSS ‚Äî The idea is you have a copy of something (like some text) then use CSS transforms to flip it vertically and apply some extra styling. It‚Äôs a neat¬†effect.

Preethi (CSS Tricks)

Generating SVG 'Mountain Ridge' Dividers ‚Äî I see this as being a bit more like a ‚Äòtorn paper‚Äô effect, but whatever it‚Äôs called, it‚Äôs neat to see how to generate SVG on the fly to represent¬†it.

Alistair Shepherd

Level-Up Your Cypress Testing Knowledge for Free

Cypress.io sponsor

Creating the DigitalOcean Logo in 3D with CSS ‚Äî Finally DigitalOcean are taking full advantage of their acquisition of CSS Tricks(!) :-) Regardless of the commercial intent, this tutorial digs a lot further into using CSS to create and work with logos and symbols than I expected and should be a learning experience for¬†all.

Jhey Tompkins

items.content:
Frontend Focus

üá∫üá¶ #‚Äã539 ‚Äî April 27, 2022 | Read on the web

'Web Color Is Still Broken' ‚Äî Whether it's handling display profiles, transparency, scaling, or color mixing, the author claims one thing is clear: ‚Äúthe web is still doing color wrong‚Äù. Here‚Äôs the Hacker News discussion on this issue, with plenty of food for thought on this complex¬†matter.

Hector Martin

Lexical: An Extensible Text Editor Library (That Does Things Differently) ‚Äî Fresh out of Meta (Facebook) comes a new text editor framework that puts accessibility, performance, and reliability at its heart. It‚Äôs only 22KB gzipped, and a (native) iOS version is on the way too.

Meta

üìë PDF:¬†Taking the Journey from Zero to 100 Deploys a Day ‚Äî Elite teams capable of deploying many times a day didn't get there overnight. This book breaks down how they did it in 3 phases: Deploy 1x a week ‚Üí 1x a day ‚Üí many times a day. By Dylan Etkin, formerly a founding engineer of Jira at¬†Atlassian.

Sleuth sponsor

The Ultimate Guide to Push Notifications for Developers ‚Äî If you find yourself needing to implement notifications, then it will become clear quickly that they can be tricky to get right. Here‚Äôs an explainer on how to implement them and which practices are best to¬†follow.

Lee Munroe

A Practical Guide to Centering in CSS ‚Äî This reference explains various methods to center elements using CSS, including techniques for Grid & Flexbox. Quite possibly the most evergreen of frontend topics. üòÖ

Alex Ivanovs

‚ö°Ô∏è Quick bits:

  • European data protection authorities have made Google add a 'Reject All' option to their cookie banner.
  • üèÜ The W3Cs WebFonts Working Group just won an Emmy for their work on the standardization of font technology.
  • Google I/O returns next month ‚Äî details here.

üìô Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Non-Interactive Elements with the inert Attribute ‚Äî How the inert attribute provides an efficient way to hide elements from assistive technology and disable element interactions such as being focused, clicked, edited, or¬†selected. FYI, this property is currently in the Safari 15.5 beta.

Tim Nguyen (WebKit)

Reducing Spam From mailto Links ‚Äî Not necessarily the best way to solve this age old problem (I remember seeing JavaScript being used for this in the 90s!) but an interesting¬†approach.

Jack Childs

Build Internal Tools in Minutes with Retool, Where Visual Programming Meets the Power of Real Code ‚Äî Custom dashboards, admin panels, CRUD apps‚Äîbuild any internal tool faster in¬†Retool.

Retool sponsor

Evaluating Design System Adoption using Custom CSS ‚Äî How one team uses custom user CSS to easily and visually audit component and design token usage in its live¬†products.

Steve Dennis

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Animate From display: none ‚Äî Here‚Äôs a useful tutorial going through how to animate when working with display: none ‚Äî a non animatable¬†property.

Kevin Powell

Mastering CSS Transitions with React 18 ‚Äî How to use the new useTransition hook that arrived with React 18 to perform a wide variety of web animation¬†effects.

Amazing Enrich Agu (OpenReplay)

How to Generate a Full Tailwind CSS Palette from a Single Color
Luka Peharda

Why Brave and DuckDuckGo Are Cracking Down on Google‚Äôs AMP
Ivan Mehta

Iva Kop

Sarah Daily

Fluid Type Scale: Generate Responsive Font-Size Variables ‚Äî Generate font size variables for a fluid type scale with CSS clamp. Grab the output CSS and drop it into any design¬†system.

Aleksandr Hovhannisyan

Test Your Web App for Accessibility. Free axe DevTools Chrome¬†Extension

Deque sponsor

Feedback Fin: An Open Source Widget to Collect Feedback Anywhere on Your Site ‚Äî Just drop in the script and add a few lines to initiate the widget, which is customizable and¬†accessible.

Linear-Style Cursor Glow ‚Äî This is a lovely little motion effect, adding a cursor glow that illuminates the currently hovered element. Recreated here using CSS variables, radial gradients and an inset. It's inspired by the Linear¬†site, as explained in this tweet.
